stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on detailing and implementing new features in 'Oily Boily Bay' (Course 11), focusing on a subterranean industrial area. Key activities included creating dynamic hydraulic platforms, collaborating with Biobak to solve a complex texture memory issue, and brainstorming the visual design for boiling oil/tar pits. The stream also covered his future plans for a commercial Unreal Engine game and his content strategy for YouTube.

development_findings.summary: The game is estimated to be 75-80% complete, with the current work focused on Course 11 of a planned 15 total courses.
Kaze's approach to creating a difficulty curve is to reserve more complex and challenging platforming sections for later levels, ensuring that difficulty is tied to rewarding gameplay moments.
development_findings.quote: I don't try to make the levels more difficult. I just put the threshold of how cool a jump has to be for it to be worth the difficulty lower.

development_findings.summary: A known bug with broken door animations is intentionally being left unfixed, as the team is waiting on a new quaternion-based animation exporter from animator Lilaa which will require re-implementing the fix.
development_findings.quote: We are changing some things about the animations. And until we have Lila's quaternion animation exporter... we cannot fix the doors.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented new hydraulic piston platforms in the 'Oily Boily Bay' underground area to make the industrial environment feel more dynamic and alive with moving machinery.
Kaze is planning a significant technical change to the 30 FPS mode by merging the rendering and gameplay threads, which he expects will improve performance.
development_findings.quote: I am planning to make it so that if you are in 30 FPS mode... the rendering thread goes into the gameplay thread. And that will allow us to increase the FPS, actually.

development_findings.summary: After researching reference videos of boiling tar, Kaze decided the oil pits in the level should be visually represented as dark, highly reflective, and feature smoke and bubble effects.
development_findings.quote: This is going to be oil... It's a very important part of the machinery. Part of the refining process.

development_findings.summary: The file select screen is designed as a playable 3D level, similar to Super Mario Sunshine, to immerse the player immediately without menus.
development_findings.quote: The game boots you directly into the file select. The game doesn't waste your time. That is important to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a critical view of modern game design, believing it serves as a time-waster rather than providing meaningful experiences, which informs his own design philosophy for RTYI.
context_findings.quote: Modern game design is made for people that are depressed and just want to erase time. Not for people that want to go have an experience.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to leverage the release of RTYI to launch a Kickstarter for a new, original commercial platformer built in Unreal Engine.
context_findings.quote: Simultaneously with the release of Return to Yoshi's Island we are going to start a Kickstarter for this game in Unreal Engine and then we will make big money.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has adopted a disciplined workflow, setting and meeting daily deadlines to maintain progress on bug fixing and level design.
context_findings.quote: I started setting myself deadlines for stuff to work on right so I've done this for 14 days now and so far I fit every single deadline with these.

context_findings.summary: While the game's source code will be made public, Kaze does not expect a fan-made PC port to ever materialize due to the project's complexity.
context_findings.quote: I will make a public source like anyone will be able to look at the code but I seriously doubt anyone is gonna have the skill to make a pc port of this or the patience because it's just gonna take so long.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release the game's soundtrack as a physical album on an N64-style cartridge that functions as a music player ROM, and intends to purchase the rights from the composer.
context_findings.quote: When RTYI releases, I want to pay the musician to have the rights to the music and then release an album for RTYI. I think that would be very fun. And the album would be like an N64 cartridge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses the financial realities of being a YouTuber, noting a significant increase in ad revenue during the Christmas season and mentioning a potential sponsorship from Honkai Star Rail.
context_findings.quote: The ad revenue on YouTube is so high. I'm making bank around Christmas. Like, holy shit. You suddenly just get a 50% pay raise if you are a YouTuber.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a high-resolution sail texture which exceeded N64 memory limits, leading to a real-time collaborative problem-solving session where Kaze devised a non-standard 96x42 pixel resolution to make it fit.
biobak.quote: Does this work for you, Biobak? This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen.

zeina.summary: Zeina corroborated Kaze's memory of a lost 'Hot Tub Mario 64' mod he created, highlighting her awareness of his past modding work.

key_stories.title: The Cursed Texture
key_stories.summary: Biobak provided a texture that was too large for the N64's memory. To solve this, Kaze devised and implemented a highly unusual 96x42 pixel resolution, demonstrating a creative technical workaround born from direct collaboration.
key_stories.challenge: A high-resolution sail texture provided by Biobak was too large for the N64's limited texture memory (TMEM).
key_stories.process: Kaze analyzed the 4096-byte TMEM limit and realized standard texture dimensions wouldn't work. He experimented with unusual divisors, arriving at a 96x42 pixel format, which he then sent back to Biobak for approval.
key_stories.outcome: They successfully fit the texture into memory by using the highly unconventional 96x42 resolution, preserving the artistic detail while adhering to strict hardware limitations.
key_stories.key_quote: Does this work for you, Biobak? This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen.

key_stories.title: The Death and Return of Lilaa
key_stories.summary: When animator Lilaa was absent for a week, Kaze and his community started a running gag that she had passed away. This joke underscored a real project dependency: her work on 'quaternion animations' is required to fix a known bug with doors, revealing the team's interconnected workflow through humor.
key_stories.challenge: Animator Lilaa, responsible for a critical animation update, was absent from the community for a week, halting progress on fixing broken door animations.
key_stories.process: Kaze and his stream chat created a running joke that Lilaa had passed away. They held a mock 'burial' and frequently referenced her 'death' in the context of the project being blocked by her absence.
key_stories.outcome: Lilaa eventually reappeared in the chat, confused by the gag. The incident humorously highlighted a real project dependency, as her 'quaternion animations' are essential for fixing a significant bug.
key_stories.key_quote: We all thought you died, Leela. Is the post saying Leela is dead? Yes, that's true.

key_stories.title: The Lost Media Marketing Ploy
key_stories.summary: Kaze's search for a 'lost' controversial mod he once made led to an unconventional idea. He decided he could leverage the mod's rediscovery as a shocking and humorous component of a sponsored video, blending his past work with his current business strategy.
key_stories.challenge: While discussing sponsorships, Kaze recalled a 'Hot Tub Mario 64' mod he created years ago but could not find it anywhere, believing it to be lost media.
key_stories.process: Kaze searched his channels, romhacking sites, and old direct messages. After finding a potential lead, he immediately connected the idea of this 'lost' controversial mod to a potential sponsorship deal with Honkai Star Rail.
key_stories.outcome: The search led Kaze to a file he'd sent to another streamer, and he brainstormed the idea of releasing the provocative lost mod as part of a sponsorship video, turning a piece of his history into a bold marketing move.
key_stories.key_quote: Release it for the Honkai Sponsorship? Oh, that is so insane. That is such a good idea.
